items.title: Please release the latest change into pypi.org
items.body:
@necaris Thanks for resolve PostgreSQL package issue, is there any plan or schedule to release this change to https://pypi.org/project/python3-openid/ as a new version?

_Originally posted by @earthday in https://github.com/necaris/python3-openid/pull/49#issuecomment-647885074_

items.title: Logging is using the root logger
items.body:
I noticed that all the log calls are direct to the root logger, which isn't ideal.

FWIW this was fixed in python-openid2 in https://github.com/ziima/python-openid/commit/95a143cc06edae839178c9d99d6c89dc43b99d40

items.title: `defusedxml` dependency doesn't support Python 3.6
items.body: Revealed by #34, requires https://github.com/tiran/defusedxml/pull/5 to be merged (and a release made) to fix. May look into hacking around the problem.

items.title: TypeError: unorderable types: Association() < Association()
items.body:
I have this error with python3 using django framework:

`TypeError: unorderable types: Association() < Association()`

This error occurred when 2 or more record in the openid_associations table have the same value for the "issued" column."

And I debugged at line 245 in python3-openid/openid/store/sqlstore.py
```
245             print(associations)
246             if associations:
247                 associations.sort()
248                 return associations[-1][1]
249             else:
250                 return None
```
It's result is..
`[(1480070610, <openid.association.Association HMAC-SHA1 b30a6665e79dd5af>), (1480070610, <openid.association.Association HMAC-SHA1 cacca1f99cd2dc4d>)]`

Data type "Association" is compared when "issued" are same value, but it can't be comparative.

items.title: Backport to Python 2.7?
items.body: It would be convenient if there weren't divergent packages for Python 2 and 3 -- if this could support 2.7 as well, that would solve that problem for most Python 2 users.

items.title: Wheel support
items.body:
http://pythonwheels.com/

Right now, only the `tar.gz` file is being distributed on PyPI for [python3-openid](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/python3-openid), which isn't _that much_ of an issue, but it does add some time to installing the package.

This package should be compatible with the Wheel format, considering it doesn't appear to have any C dependencies and it is compatible with both Python 2 and 3. As a result, you should only need to generate a universal wheel and then everyone (on all systems) will get the ability to install python3-openid with just the wheel, without having to do any extra work.

items.title: ValueError: Unicode strings with encoding declaration are not supported.
items.body:
I have this error with python3 using flask-openid (which is using this library) :

`ValueError: Unicode strings with encoding declaration are not supported. Please use bytes input or XML fragments without declaration.`

It happens when I use `try_login('...')`. If I run it with python 2.7, everything is working fine. Here is the full traceback :

items.title: Python 3.5 Compatibility. HTMLParser strict arugment is removed.
items.body:
While adding test support for Python 3.5 in Django Allauth (https://github.com/pennersr/django-allauth/pull/1185) I discovered a bug in this project.

When I'm testing Django Allauth against Python 3.5 I get the following error output:

```
ERROR: test_discovery_failure (allauth.socialaccount.providers.openid.tests.OpenIDTests)

----------------------------------------------------------------------

Traceback (most recent call last):

  File "/home/travis/build/pennersr/django-allauth/allauth/socialaccount/providers/openid/tests.py", line 25, in test_discovery_failure

    dict(openid='http://www.google.com'))

  File "/home/travis/virtualenv/python3.5.0/lib/python3.5/site-packages/django/test/client.py", line 512, in post

    secure=secure, **extra)

  File "/home/travis/virtualenv/python3.5.0/lib/python3.5/site-packages/django/test/client.py", line 313, in post

    secure=secure, **extra)

  File "/home/travis/virtualenv/python3.5.0/lib/python3.5/site-packages/django/test/client.py", line 379, in generic

    return self.request(**r)

  File "/home/travis/virtualenv/python3.5.0/lib/python3.5/site-packages/django/test/client.py", line 466, in request

    six.reraise(*exc_info)

  File "/home/travis/virtualenv/python3.5.0/lib/python3.5/site-packages/django/utils/six.py", line 659, in reraise

    raise value

  File "/home/travis/virtualenv/python3.5.0/lib/python3.5/site-packages/django/core/handlers/base.py", line 132, in get_response

    response = wrapped_callback(request, *callback_args, **callback_kwargs)

  File "/home/travis/build/pennersr/django-allauth/allauth/socialaccount/providers/openid/views.py", line 38, in login

    auth_request = client.begin(form.cleaned_data['openid'])

  File "/home/travis/virtualenv/python3.5.0/lib/python3.5/site-packages/openid/consumer/consumer.py", line 343, in begin

    service = disco.getNextService(self._discover)

  File "/home/travis/virtualenv/python3.5.0/lib/python3.5/site-packages/openid/yadis/manager.py", line 105, in getNextService

    yadis_url, services = discover(self.url)

  File "/home/travis/virtualenv/python3.5.0/lib/python3.5/site-packages/openid/consumer/discover.py", line 471, in discover

    return discoverURI(identifier)

  File "/home/travis/virtualenv/python3.5.0/lib/python3.5/site-packages/openid/consumer/discover.py", line 463, in discoverURI

    claimed_id, openid_services = discoverYadis(uri)

  File "/home/travis/virtualenv/python3.5.0/lib/python3.5/site-packages/openid/consumer/discover.py", line 390, in discoverYadis

    response = yadisDiscover(uri)

  File "/home/travis/virtualenv/python3.5.0/lib/python3.5/site-packages/openid/yadis/discover.py", line 85, in discover

    result.xrds_uri = whereIsYadis(resp)

  File "/home/travis/virtualenv/python3.5.0/lib/python3.5/site-packages/openid/yadis/discover.py", line 161, in whereIsYadis

    yadis_loc = findHTMLMeta(StringIO(content))

  File "/home/travis/virtualenv/python3.5.0/lib/python3.5/site-packages/openid/yadis/parsehtml.py", line 178, in findHTMLMeta

    parser = YadisHTMLParser()

  File "/home/travis/virtualenv/python3.5.0/lib/python3.5/site-packages/openid/yadis/parsehtml.py", line 99, in __init__

    super(YadisHTMLParser, self).__init__(strict=False)

TypeError: __init__() got an unexpected keyword argument 'strict'
```

_from: https://travis-ci.org/pennersr/django-allauth/jobs/89955820_

The error is there because it calls a super with `__init__(strict=False)`. The strict argument of the HTMLParser is removed in Python 3.5. The parser now accepts and parses invalid input too. 
See https://docs.python.org/3.4/library/html.parser.html for more information. 

I'm not familiar with this code base of this project. So unfortunately I will not start working on a patch for this. Hopefully someone can fix this so we can enable testing against Python 3.5 in the Django Allauth project.

items.title: Import error due release 3.5 of Python
items.body:
With the release of Python 3.5, the HTMLParserError exception has been removed (it was deprecated since version 3.3), so now importing it results in an Import exception.

The file yadis/parsehtml.py in line 3 imports HTMLParserError.

items.title: Cleanup Nonces
items.body:
Kindly ask that we clarify how nonces are cleaned up and managed.

I have this operational, but using the FileOpenIDStore class, I am seeing Nonce being created on each login x user.  Each Logout and Login gets Nonces created each same user.  

While this makes sense, it would be good to understand how Nonce are GC'd.  And if the clients of this lib can have any control over.
In the case of the FileOpenIDStore how this can be cleaned up as these are collecting and piling up.  In the database for storing Nonce (ie. SQLStore) same would be reflected in number of records.

items.title: Examples are out of date
items.body: Update examples to Django 1.7

Hi, when I run `python3 -m unittest openid.test.test_suite`, I got the following Traceback:

AssertionError: '/success' != b'/success' ; context {'plain': <function test_fetcher.<locals>.plain at 0x7f0ccc41e830>, 'actual': <HTTPResponse status 200 for http://127.0.0.1:5058/success>, 'fetcher': <openid.fetchers.HTTPLib2Fetcher object at 0x7f0ccc42eb50>, 'path': '/success', 'cases': [('/success', <HTTPResponse status 200 for http://127.0.0.1:5058/success>), ('/301redirect', <HTTPResponse status 200 for http://127.0.0.1:5058/success>), ('/302redirect', <HTTPResponse status 200 for http://127.0.0.1:5058/success>), ('/303redirect', <HTTPResponse status 200 for http://127.0.0.1:5058/success>), ('/307redirect', <HTTPResponse status 200 for http://127.0.0.1:5058/success>), ('/notfound', <HTTPResponse status 404 for http://127.0.0.1:5058/notfound>), ('/badreq', <HTTPResponse status 400 for http://127.0.0.1:5058/badreq>), ('/forbidden', <HTTPResponse status 403 for http://127.0.0.1:5058/forbidden>), ('/error', <HTTPResponse status 500 for http://127.0.0.1:5058/error>), ('/server_error', <HTTPResponse status 503 for http://127.0.0.1:5058/server_error>)], 'geturl': <function test_fetcher.<locals>.geturl at 0x7f0ccc41e8c0>, 'fetch_url': 'http://127.0.0.1:5058/success', 'should_raise_exc': True, 'expected_headers': {'content-type': 'text/plain'}, 'server': <http.server.HTTPServer object at 0x7f0ccc42ec10>, 'expect_success': <HTTPResponse status 200 for http://127.0.0.1:5058/success>, 'expected': <HTTPResponse status 200 for http://127.0.0.1:5058/success>}

----------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 1331 tests in 1.328s

FAILED (failures=1, errors=1)
```

Am I doing anything wrong? As SyntaxError is something that should not happen during the tests, right?

items.title: Dealing with bytes in python 3.3
items.body:
In https://github.com/necaris/python3-openid/blob/master/openid/cryptutil.py#L104

Using python 3.3 I'm hitting this line and erroring. bytes[0] in python 2.7 returns a string whereas in 3.3 it's an integer. ord() then breaks because it expects a string.

Also the line after that, you can't concat bytes and a string in python 3.3.

items.title: UnicodeDecodeError on (intentionally invalid) discover
items.body:
I am running a "discover" on http://www.google.com, which should raise a DiscoveryFailure, but fails instead with a UnicodeDecodeError. For some reason it only fails when testing from Travis -- I cannot reproduce this locally. Possibly this is due to the fact that google.com is serving different content depending on the IP address of the caller.
Should fromHTML catch these errors and act accordingly (return no services) ?
    ======================================================================

```
